events.subtitle: Keynote - Iconoclasm
events.description: History is littered with the stories of iconoclasts--people who truly stood out as pioneers, lateral thinkers, and in some cases, outright heroes--and their successes and failures. From the baseball management vision of Branch Hickey to the glassblowing vision of Dale Chihuly to the engineering design vision of Steve Jobs, iconoclasts have changed our world in subtle and profound ways, sometimes loudly, sometimes quietly. For an industry that seems so ripe and so rife with 'special personalities', it would seem that programming is tied up deeply with iconoclasm. But what defines the iconoclast, what demarcates the 'true' iconoclast from the mere pretender, and how can we use the characteristics of the iconoclast to change our own immediate surroundings for the better?

events.subtitle: Java Roadmap
events.description: Straight from the source: An update on Java 8, Java 9 and new and upcoming features in Oracle's Java implementation.

events.subtitle: Genymotion, the new Android emulator
events.description: I'll will present you what Genymotion is, how it works, and why we built such a tool. I'll give you a brief history of the project, a demonstration of the main Genymotion features, and a sneak peek of what we are working on.

events.subtitle: Using Node.js for everything or what it is to write a book about it
events.description: Node.js is one of the most interesting technologies nowadays. We all know that we could run a web server and process HTTP requests. However, Node.js is a lot more and could be used for everything. In this talk we will see the various use cases of our lovely Node.js.</br></br>Before a couple of months I finished Node.js Blueprints book. It was a long 7/8 months journey and I'll be happy to share my experience. 90% of the talk is about the popular use cases of Node.js and the rest contains tips for writing about Node.js. Here are the main points:</br></br>Node.js and the popular client side frameworks like Angular, Ember and Backbone</br>Node.js and realtime</br>Node.js as a command line tool</br>Automation with Grunt and Gulp</br>Writing flexible CSS</br>Automating your tests</br>Writing Rest APIs</br>Desktop apps with Node.js

events.subtitle: 45 valuable tips for developers in 45 minutes
events.description: In this sessions Jan-Willem Eshuis takes you into a fast journey along 45 valuable tips for developers using real world practical examples. In his talk Jan-Willem covers topics like clean code, testing, deploying, hosting, infrastructure and service and support. After the 45 minutes of passion, humor and speed you'll remember at least a couple of tips to apply them in practice.

events.subtitle: Source Control, Versioning and Concurrent Development for OBIEE using Git
events.description: In this session we will look at options for integrating OBIEE 11g with source control tools including Subversion and Git, focusing on Git as our preferred SCM tool. We will look at how Git can make use of the new MDS XML Documents repository format, and see how it permits versioning of individual repository element over time. We'll also look at how Git supports concurrent development including branching and merging of repositories, and whether Git + MDS XML can replace MUDE as a platform for concurrent development of the repository.

events.subtitle: Lessons Learned from Real-World Deployments of Java EE 7
events.description: Java EE 7, released over a year ago, introduced several new technologies such as WebSocket, Batch, and JSON. There are already three compliant application servers: WildFly, GlassFish, and Tmaxsoft. NetBeans, Eclipse, and IntelliJ provide extensive tooling support for the APIs. What are the best practices for building and deploying Java EE 7 applications? What to do and not to do? This session takes three Java EE 7 applications running in production and shares lessons learned from each one. It attempts to answer questions such as Is WebSocket ready for production? How do we migrate from Spring Batch to JSR 352 batch? Any change in DevOps? Are additional libraries still needed? Which is more prominent, EJB/JSF or REST/JavaScript?

events.subtitle: The Mythical Silver Bullet - How Codename One solves mobility differently
events.description: In January 2012 Chen Fishbein and myself summed up over 28 years of combined mobile development experience to form Codename One. We built it on the extensive work we lead at Sun Microsystems but took it into a bold new direction that most major companies weren't willing to risk: the cloud.</br></br>More than 2 years later our vision has taken roots in Fortune 500 companies, banks & governments. This talk covers why Codename One is indeed a silver bullet for many use cases, why it can succeed where so many have failed and how it is moving forward with the help of the community.

events.subtitle: A deep dive into Event Store
events.description: Event Store is an ACID-compliant stream database with just 24 bytes of mutable state. It is also open source on GitHub and largely written in managed code, making it an excellent code base to start investigating database internals.</br></br>In this session we'll take a deep dive into the SEDA architecture of Event Store, from the client protocol down to the storage engine and replication model, We'll discuss some of the hard decisions and why we made them, and discuss some of the tradeoffs which must be considered when building large scale systems on a managed platform.

events.subtitle: Beyond NoSQL: NewSQL on top of Cassandra
events.description: ok.ru (AKA odnoklassniki.ru) is one of the largest social networks for Russian-speaking audiences with 80+ million unique user’s visits monthly.</br></br></br>Until recent time more than 50 TB of data at ok.ru OLTP systems was managed by Microsoft SQL Sever. It’s very expensive, hard to scale solution and cannot save us from outage if one of our data centers fail.</br>Typically a NoSQL solution is selected to address such high availability requirements, but unfortunately these all data could be migrated to NoSQL due to ACID transaction guarantees requirements.</br>So we implemented a NewSQL system, which provides scalable performance and availability of NoSQL while still maintaining the ACID guarantees and deployed it to production.</br>We’ll discuss the internals of the new storage and its operational experience. This talk could be of interest for anyone who follows the development of database technologies and has experience with (No)SQL implementations.

events.subtitle: 9 use cases for Oracle SQL Developer Data Modeler
events.description: Data Modeler is known to be an amazing tool for database design. But are there any other use cases for the tool? In this presentation Heli will explain how to use the tool for database design and 8 other use cases.

events.subtitle: Java EE 8, a snapshot overview!
events.description: Java EE 7 was released 18 months ago and from J2EE to Java EE 7, much has changed but we are not done yet! Through the years, Java EE has always reinventing itself. Java EE 8 will be no exception to this rule!</br></br>In this session, we will look at the Java EE 8 plans. We will review the various new JSRs that will be part of Java EE 8 (e.g. MVC JSR, JSON-B JSR, Security JSR, Configuration JSR...). We will obviously also looks how the existing technologies will evolves for Java EE 8 (eg. Servlet 4 with the HTTP 2 support, JMS's plan to replace Message Driven Beans, CDI/EJB alignment, etc).</br></br>We will conclude by looking at how the community can get involved in those works.

events.subtitle: Beyond Development - Operating a Product at Light Speed
events.description: So you know how to develop and ship a product. </br>What comes next is an endless uphill battle to measure, polish, update and analyze your product performance.</br>You'll get insights on how easy it is nowdays to run marketing campaigns and measure their performance, learn insights on what it takes to ship a product to all mobile and desktop platform app stores, including App Store, Google Play, OS X, Windows Store and Windows Phone...

events.subtitle: CompletableFuture is here
events.description: Many have said that Java has no future. But it is now 2014, the new java.time. *, stream-style and trendy lambda dances in Java 8. And a crowd of advanced neighbors​​ that have their own means of asynchronous processing for 'going to production quickly.'' </br></br>Let's talk about other languages ​​and libraries a bit. Buf of JDK 5, we already had Future and ExecutorService for asynchronous execution. However, with the advent of CompletableFuture in JDK 8, the way opened from callback hell to clean and more functional code.</br></br>We look at practical examples of the challenges CompletableFuture 'with streams and lambdas' takes and it's efficiency.

events.subtitle: Enterprise flight into DevOps space
events.description: Enterprise adoption of DevOps is something that is already happening, but like with other trendy methodologies it happens quite differently with different level of success. This presentation accumulates speaker's experience in helping different size organizations to implement DevOps initiatives and gives interesting real life examples: war stories, jokes, myths. </br></br>During last years we accumulated a lot of experience helping our clients automating their JVM projects starting from automated deployments and ending with fully automated production infrastructure configuration.

events.subtitle: PL/SQL : Stop Making The Same Performance Mistakes
events.description: PL/SQL is great, but like any programming language it is capable of being misused. Rather than listing a bunch of 'best practices', this presentation highlights the common mistakes made when developing in PL/SQL, turning what should be an elegant solution into a resource hog. With live demonstrations, this presentation will help you get the best performance from your PL/SQL.

events.subtitle: Lambda Expressions In Java: Going Beyond the Basics
events.description: Lambda expressions were introduced in Java SE 8 to replace many uses of inner classes and greatly simplify how we can parameterise behaviour as well as values in our code.  Lambda expressions made the Streams API possible without having to write huge amounts of boiler-plate code.  This session will look in some depth at details of Lambda expressions, both from how to use them and how they are implemented, as well as provide some ideas about how to approach debugging.  We'll look at a number of examples of Lambda expressions and explain how they work and some key points that you should be aware of to use them as effectively as possible.

events.subtitle: How to Become the MacGyver of Android Custom Views
events.description: MacGyver is part Indiana Jones, part Sherlock Holmes. He can turn a bicycle frame into a blowtorch, disarm a bomb with a hockey ticket, create a time machine with some duct tape and a paper clip or CREATE A CUSTOM VIEW IN ANDROID. </br></br>In this talk we will walk through the Android UI framework and learn how to push it to the next level by learning how views work and how to build custom ones that will let us create innovative UIs.

events.subtitle: The Busy Javascript Developer’s Guide to MEAN
events.description: The MEAN Stack (Mongo, Express, Angular, Node) has taken the open-source world by storm, and many developers consider it to be 'the next big thing' in the world of building Web-based applications. In this lecture, we're going to embrace our inner JavaScript and build a simple application from scratch using the MEANJS package, including tests against the server-side API and the client-side UI. We'll talk about how Node works on the server, how the various Node packages combine, and examine one such package (MeanJS) that collects several Node packages together to create a (somewhat) seamless development experience, while still leaving room for extension and/or replacement if desired or necessary.

events.subtitle: Smart Home Development Made Easy
events.description: 2014 was the year of the Smart Home - not only have Apple, Google/Nest and Samsung/SmartThings entered the stage, but there was a lot of buzz around the Internet of Things in general and Smart Homes in particular. After the 'smartphone battle' the 'smarthome battle' is now at the horizon for this year. Wouldn't it be great to escape from this battle and use something truly open and independent instead?</br></br>The Eclipse SmartHome project fills this gap. It was initiated by the popular open-source project openHAB, which makes it possible to realize advanced vendor-independent home automation use cases in no time. While openHAB's target audience were so far tech-savvy people and early adopters, the Eclipse SmartHome project leads the way from the niche to the mass market by fostering industry adoption as it provides a flexible framework with many options for building Smart Home solutions. </br></br>This session includes live hacking and you will of course see a smart home live demo that goes way beyond the standard use cases.

events.subtitle: The best of both worlds : Going hybrid with your mobile APEX Oracle Application
events.description: According to Gartner in 2015 50% of all mobile applications will be hybrid. So it is the right time to jump on the bandwagon and start building hybrid mobile applications yourself. And you don't need to know Java, Object C, C++ or other 'strange' languages. Using Oracle Application Express and PhoneGap / Cordova you can create awesome looking and functioning near-to-native applications. In this session we will go through a step-by-step example of an application that synchronises the (native) Contacts on your phone with your customer database.

events.subtitle: Effective Design of RESTful APIs
events.description: Developers creating websites needs to know how to build RESTful APIs correctly. This session will help you plan and model your own APIs and understand the six REST design constraints that help guide your architecture. I will starts with a simple overview, including advice on identifying the users or 'participants' of your system and the activities they might perform with it. I'll help you paper test your model, validating the design before you build it. You'll then explore the HTTP concepts and REST constraints needed to build your API. </br></br>Topics include:</br>The three approaches to adding an API, Modeling tips, Creating and grouping API methods, Mapping activities to, verbs and actions, Validating your API, Working with HTTP headers and response codes, Caching, Layered systems, Creating a uniform interface.</br></br>All those explanations topics will be provided by examples to clear up the idea and demonstrate the concept.

events.subtitle: Android Wear deep dive
events.description: Android Wear from glanceable notifications to the deep view of what are the limits of what is possible on such small form factor.

events.subtitle: Nuts and Bolts of WebSocket
events.description: WebSocket provides a rich and powerful communication channel where client and server can communicate with each other in a standard way. JavaScript API in Web browsers is also quite prevalent making it easier to support it.</br></br>Would you like to learn how to build WebSocket applications in Java ? How and where do you deploy these applications ? What are the concerns around firewall, DNS and routers ? How do you debug message exchanges ? What to do if WebSocket is not supported in the browser or app server ? Debugging and Production tips ? Learn about phantom WebSockets.</br></br>This university session is for you! Here is what we'll cover:</br></br>Introduction to WebSocket</br>WebSocket using JSR 356</br>WebSocket using Undertow/WildFly</br>WebSocket using Atmosphere</br>Surviving Firewall and Proxy</br>WebSocket Debugging</br>WebSocket Production Tips

events.subtitle: JVM crash dump analysis
events.description: Java Virtual Machine can handle a wide range of coding errors by throwing an exception with a readable stack trace. But what to do if JVM crashes on its own? What is hs_err.log, the only postmortem message with mysterious contents?</br></br>This talk will shed light on the information encoded in crash dumps. We will see how this data is useful in problem investigation. The live demo will review the real cases of JVM crash and postmortem analysis.

events.subtitle: No Silver Bullets - OBIEE Performance in the Real World
events.description: Are you involved in the design and development of OBIEE systems and want to know the best way to go about ensuring good performance? Maybe you've an existing OBIEE system with performance 'challenges' that you need to diagnose?</br>This presentation looks at the practical elements of diagnosing the causes of performance issues in OBIEE, and discusses good practices to observe when developing new systems.

events.subtitle: 'Catch me if you can' - Java on wearables
events.description: Wearable computers are one of the next big things. But at the moment, one can buy only specialized systems such as motion trackers, GPS watches, and the like. So why not use existing cheap technology to build your own wearable Java-powered device? This session shows what you can do with affordable technology and Java today. It uses a Raspberry Pi in combination with a heart rate sensor and a GPS sensor to track the heart rate and the location of a runner. The battery-powered Pi measures the data and publishes it via MQTT to different clients such as Java(FX)-based desktop clients and a smartwatch the runner can wear. Come get some ideas of what you can do with Java and wearable devices.

events.subtitle: Introduction to Google Glass development
events.description: Google Glass is an futuristic and controversial device. What possibilities are there for developers? Come to learn up-to-date information about the platform. All the code examples will be taken from an open-source production app used by Glass Explorers on daily basis.

events.subtitle: Java Concurrency Under the Hood
events.description: In this age when parallelism matters, being able to write proper concurrent code is paramount. While Java hides lots of implementation details by its 'Write Once, Run Anywhere' motto, all abstractions will eventually leak. When they do, you will have to go deeper and see how that thing actually works.

events.subtitle: Programming Bitcoin in Java
events.description: The first half of this talk will cover what bitcoin is as well as a  technical overview of how it works.  The second part will focus on how Java developers can use the open-source bitcoinj library to program the bitcoin blockchain to send and receive payments as well as create smart contracts.</br></br>For more details on bitcoinj, see https://bitcoinj.github.io/

events.subtitle: An Oracle DBA's Guide to WebLogic Server
events.description: WebLogic Server is Oracle's flagship Java application server and a pivotal piece of the infrastructure supporting many of their applications, including Fusion Apps and Enterprise Manager Cloud Control. This session introduces the basic concepts behind WebLogic Server and discusses the installation, configuration and management of systems to support both ADF and Oracle Forms/Reports applications. The presentation is aimed at those who are new to WebLogic Server, especially DBAs who are increasingly being expected to know about middle-tier administration.
